sentence: SAP AG CEOBill McDermott is nothing if not bold.
He's not only overhauling the venerable software giant's business model but making an audacious prediction.

"We will not waver or bend until we have taken over the CRM (customer relationship management) market," he said at SAP's (ticker: SAP) annual Sapphire customer conference in Orlando, Fla.

Say again?
Software's fastest-growing segment, at $39.5 billion market, in which Salesforce.com (CRM) is the dominate player?

SAP this week rolled out its biggest product makeover in years -- it combines sales, marketing, and customer service software into a suite of tools called C/4HANA linked to its business planning system -- and acquired CoreSystems, a Swiss firm specializing in customer service software in its pursuit of business customers.
McDermott refers to the single-integrated software suite as SAP's "master plan to disrupt CRM."

The new software also covers commerce, customer service, and consumer data protection tools, which SAP sees as a weakness in older, predominately sales-focused platforms now that the General Data Protection Regulation is in effect.

McDermott says "simple solutions in the cloud" in sales automation and human resources, for example, have increased in importance since the 2008 financial crisis, leading to "fragmentation" in enterprise software.
SAP, he's convinced, has a "real shot" at integrating CRM with enterprise resource planning -- a fancy way of saying running a company's core business in real-time -- in a way its competitors cannot.
If that sounds ambitious, it might be because Salesforce is the global market leader and SAP is playing catch up, says Ed Thompson, a software analyst at market researcher Gartner.
At 18.8%, Salesforce has more than twice SAP's share (8.5%) and is growing faster than the market rate.
Oracle (ORCL) is third in the market, which Thompson expects to top $75 billion in 2022.
"It's a good move by SAP to consolidate [its technologies] in the CRM market," Thompson says.
"It will appeal to the SAP faithful and make those confused by SAP's strategy think again about considering alternatives.
But it is defensive in response to Salesforce."

The rub, Thompson says, is assuring that SAP customers make the transition to a retooled technology and that SAP evolves its ecosystem as CRM rivals Oracle, Adobe Systems (ADBE), and Pegasystems (PEGA) have by creating marketplaces of apps.
But SAP has clearly moved in the right direction, Thompson says, as the software industry changes.

The world's third-largest independent software company, with $27.96 billion in 2017 revenue, has been shifting from big-ticket software sales to one deeply invested in slicing and dicing data to make companies smarter.

It's teamed with companies such as Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), Alphabet's Google (GOOGL), and Microsoft (MSFT) to bring innovations like blockchain, machine learning, artificial intelligence, and the internet of things to the business world.
And it is growing: Company shares are up 6% this year, and SAP's market value has increased from $39 billion in 2010 - when McDermott became co-CEO - to $144.7 billion today.
(McDermott was named sole CEO in 2014.)
The question now is whether SAP's CRM ambitions meet McDermott's lofty expectations, fueling the next phase of the company's growth.
